clinical_study.brief_title: Drug Abuse Prevention Among Girls Through a Mother-Daughter Intervention
clinical_study.official_title: Drug Abuse Prevention Among Girls Through a Mother-Daughter Intervention

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine a computer- and family-based drug abuse prevention program is able to reduce drug use among early adolescent girls.

detailed_description.textblock: This study longitudinally tested a computerized, parent-involvement substance abuse prevention program for adolescent girls and their mothers. The prevention program aimed to strengthen and sustain the mother-daughter bond while equipping girls with the necessary information and skills to increase protective factors and reduce risk factors associated with tobacco, alcohol, and other harmful substance use.

primary_outcome.description: Measured 30-day alcohol, tobacco, and other illicit drug use among girls.

secondary_outcome.description: Communication, Closeness, Family rules, Monitoring, Body esteem, Depression, Coping ability, Normative beliefs, Problem solving, Refusal Intentions

intervention.description: 9-session computerized cognitive behavioral program that young girls and their mothers interact with on a weekly basis in the privacy of their home.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- English-speaking NYC area girls
- Ages 11 - 13 years
- Must have private access to a computer with high-speed connectivity
Exclusion Criteria:
- Non-English-speaking girls who do not live in the NYC area
- Younger than 11 or older than 13 years of age
- Those who lack of private access to a computer with high-speed connectivity

responsible_party.investigator_title: D'Elbert and Selma Keenan Professor of Social Work
